title-group.article-title: Anti-windup linear parameter varying control of structural systems with magneto-rheological dampers

article-meta.aff: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Houston, Houston, TX, USA

author-notes.corresp: Mona Meisami-Azad, Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204, USA Email: mona.meisami@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Magneto-rheological (MR) dampers are a family of semi-active devices widely used for vibration attenuation in space and civil engineering structures. In this paper, we study the use of MR dampers for seismic protection of a model two-story structure in the presence of actuation saturation. A modified Bingham model is considered for linear parameter varying (LPV) modeling and control of the system. The main contribution of the paper is the design and experimental validation of a LPV anti-windup compensator to tackle the effect of actuator saturation on the control design performance. The designed LPV anti-windup control scheme is advantageous from the implementation standpoint because it can be considered as an addition to the existing control system. Experimental results demonstrate the ability of the design method to attenuate the effects of seismic excitation by controlling the MR damper and simultaneously avoid the adverse effects of actuator saturation by taking advantage of the designed anti-windup compensator and leading to savings in power consumption.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Base isolation is one of the most widely accepted seismic protection schemes. Seismic base isolation techniques lead to the mitigation of the effects of an earthquake by isolating the structure and its components from potentially dangerous ground motion, particularly within the frequency range where the building is most affected (Kelly and Naeim, 1999). The primary objective in base isolation is to simultaneously, and in a cost-effective way, reduce interstory drifts and floor accelerations to limit damage to both the structure and its components (Ramallo and Spencer, 2002). Ramallo and Spencer (2002) and Kelly (1986) discuss different methods for base isolation and their implementation and efficacy.

Magneto-rheological (MR) dampers are semi-active devices utilizing MR fluids. The MR fluid has the ability to transform into a near solid material in milliseconds when exposed to a magnetic field. It can return to its original liquid state, equally fast upon the removal of the magnetic field. The effect can be seen as a very large change in its effective viscosity. This allows the damping characteristics to be continuously controlled by varying the voltage applied to the MR damper. This semi-active device has been shown to be promising in seismic vibration reduction in civil engineering structures due to its desirable mechanical properties (Spencer et al., 1997). MR dampers have been additionally applied in a number of other applications including aerospace systems (Kamath et al., 1999; Choi and Wereley, 2003), biomedical applications (Kim and Oh, 2001) and automotive suspension systems (Yao et al., 2002). MR dampers have also been utilized to develop base isolation strategies for protection of building structures (Yoshioka et al., 2002; Bani-Hani and Sheban, 2006; Lin et al., 2007).

Various models in the literature have been proposed to capture the dynamics of MR dampers. The Bingham model is an idealized mechanical model based on the Bingham behavior. This model uses a Coulomb friction element in parallel with a viscous damper (Spencer et al., 1997). The Bouc-Wen model is another model used to account for hysteresis in MR damper modeling (Dyke et al., 1996; Pan et al., 2000). The LuGre model is a simpler model with fewer number of parameters and has been used effectively in combination with adaptive parameter estimation methods (Sakai et al., 2005). Black-box approaches have also been used in modeling and identification of MR dampers (Savaresi et al., 2005). In addition, a neural network approach has been developed for both identification and control of MR dampers (Guo et al., 2004). A comprehensive review of modeling, identification and validation techniques for MR dampers is reported by Wang and Liao (2011).

Different MR damper control strategies have been proposed in the past. One control scheme that has received a lot of attention is the so-called clipped optimal control (Jansen and Dyke, 2000). Erkus et al. (2002) applied the clipped optimal control method for vibration reduction of elevated highway bridges, where they compared performance of the linear-quadratic regulator (LQR)-clipped optimal controller with that of passive and active LQR controllers. Jansen and Dyke (2000) carried out a comparative study between various control methods for MR damper control, including a Lyapunov-based controller, a decentralized bang–bang controller, maximum energy dissipation, a clipped optimal controller and modulated homogenous friction. The controllers were tested for vibration reduction of a six-story building exposed to large earthquake excitations. Poussot-Vassal et al. (2008) designed and implemented a controller in the linear parameter varying (LPV) framework for semi-actively controlled devices to ensure stability, improved performance and robustness. It is noted that the gain-scheduled control design method by Poussot-Vassal et al. (2008) does not consider a LPV model that explicitly incorporates the MR damper properties. Sakai et al. (2005) formulated the integrated design problem of plant (including MR damper) parameters and ℋ∞ feedback control gains as a bilinear matrix inequality optimization problem. (Du et al., 2005) also developed and tested an ℋ∞ controller for MR-based vibration suppression in a quarter car model. Guo et al. (2004) used a neuro-network approach in a MR cable vibration suppression, where a neural network-based controller was designed to emulate linear-quadratic-Gaussian (LQG) and clipped LQG controllers.

Anti-windup control design is employed to account for the cases where the calculated controller input is different from the signal that is actually applied to the plant. Actuator saturation is one of the main reasons why anti-windup compensation is utilized. Actuator saturation can result in undesirable effects on control system stability and performance (Campo and Morari, 1990). Some of the adverse effects of actuator saturation include: (i) destabilization of control systems through a decrease in feedback gain; (ii) severe performance degradation particularly when integrators are used in the linear compensator since after saturation occurs, the error signal is continuously integrated, due to the presence of the integrator in the loop, leading to the reset-windup and consequently to large overshoots and sluggish response; and (iii) altering the direction of the control input vector in the multi-variable systems. It is noted that, in the present work, stability is not an issue due to the passivity of the system. The goal of anti-windup compensation is to modify the nominal control action so that if the signal from the controller is different from that entering the plant, a corrective feedback action is applied to reduce the discrepancy. There are two approaches to anti-windup control where the first one takes the saturation nonlinearity into account at the beginning of the controller design process and in the other one the linear controller is designed first followed by a modification to compensate for the saturation effects. As an example of the first approach, Teel (1995) proposed low-gain controllers using ℋ∞ optimal control theory. Nguyen and Jabbari (2000) formulated an anti-windup control design problem for the amplitude and rate saturation nonlinearities in the form of a convex optimization problem through linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Owing to the combination of various requirements, this single-step approach may become conservative and quite complicated. An early review of the anti-windup control methods was reported by Edwards and Postlethwaite (1998) and the anti-windup compensator synthesis problem was approached in an ℋ∞ framework in this paper. An overview of recent advances in anti-windup control techniques is presented by Tarbouriech and Turner (2009).

Do et al. (2010) proposed a LPV modeling and control design approach for a quarter car suspension model using a MR damper. The objective is to improve passenger comfort, as well as maintaining the road holding capacity where the resulting controller provides MR damper force as the output. Saturation dynamics effects are not considered by Do et al. (2010). As an extension of the work by Do et al. (2010), Lozoya-Santos et al. (2010) formulate the problem of suspension system control with a nonlinear MR damper model and the saturation dynamics of MR damper in a LPV framework considering the current as the control input. To this end, the saturation is substituted with a tangent hyperbolic term and that is taken into account in the LPV model. Unfortunately, there is limited information showing the effectiveness of the control design in dealing with the actuator saturation. In fact, the authors have only shown two plots illustrating the saturation effect and argue that the medium and high MR damping value lead to the maximum current applied to the damper to achieve the desired force. However, they do not address the more important problem of how to revise the control law to avoid the saturation effect concluding that the saturation has an influence on the performance in a complex manner.

In this paper, we design a LPV anti-windup compensator for a two-story building prototype using a MR damper for base isolation and vibration attenuation. It is experimentally validated that under some earthquake excitations the controllable voltage of MR damper exceeds the allowable upper and lower voltage limits resulting in performance degradation, as well as a high power consumption. However, with the use of an anti-windup compensator we are able to: (i) keep the MR damper voltage within an allowable range and hence maintain the power consumption in a low level; and (ii) maintain the closed-loop system performance. This is indeed beneficial in the sense that many semi-active devices operate on battery power, which is critical during seismic events when the main power source to the structure may fail and the battery is a limited power source. In our work, the LPV anti-windup controller designed to minimize the adverse effect of the saturation is integrated with a nominal controller. The synthesis condition for an anti-windup compensator design is formulated as a LMI optimization problem that can be solved efficiently. It should be noted that the objective of this work is not to compare the performance of the LPV controllers with some other types of passive or active control methods such as optimal passive damping or clipped optimal control (Dyke et al., 1996; Jansen and Dyke, 2000). Such comparisons have already been reported, e.g. by Shirazi et al. (2011), and the LPV controller was shown to outperform the optimal passive damping and clipped optimal methods in terms of lower maximum acceleration and root mean square (RMS) values of the structure response. Our goal is instead to show the improvements achieved by using anti-windup LPV controllers compared to the standard LPV controllers in terms of linear performance recovery and graceful performance degradation from the actuator saturation. The basic advantage of using control design methods of the present paper and the work by Shirazi et al. (2011) compared with the clipped optimal control method is described in the following. The clipped optimal approach is popular because of its design simplicity; however, this method has the disadvantage that it changes the voltage of the MR damper from zero to its maximum value without any intermediate voltage supply. In fact, it does not take the limitations of the control devices into account and saturation is imposed in such a way that the method typically does not produce optimal controllers. The rapid change in voltage might lead to a sudden rise in the external control force which increases the system responses (Scruggs et al., 2007). The control design methods proposed in the present paper and the work by Shirazi et al. (2011), however, provide control laws resulting in smooth changes in the MR damper voltage.

The present paper is organized as follows: Section 2 describes the experimental setup. In Section 3, the LPV modeling and control design method is briefly explained. The formulation and design procedure for the LPV anti-windup compensator is covered in Section 4. The benefit of the proposed control design method through several sets of experiments is shown in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. Experimental setup
sec.p:
The experimental setup used in this work is shown in Figure 1. It consists of the following main parts: the shaking table and its driving components, a two-story model building, the MR damper, and sensors for displacement and acceleration measurements. The base-isolated two-story model building is supported by a slider with low friction providing the base isolation. The base mass consists of the slider mass and a 205.7 × 50.69 × 6.51 mm3 aluminum plate. The mass of the first and second floors consist of the same aluminum plate and additional weights. The side plates are aluminum beams with dimensions of 17.60 × 50.69 × 0.75 mm3. Two springs with the total stiffness of 1057 N/m are symmetrically attached to the base mass to restrict the base drift. The shaking table used in this study is the Shaker II by Quanser company that can provide ±7.5 cm maximum displacement, ±83.8 cm/s peak velocity, and ±24.5 m/s2 peak acceleration with a 930 kg bearing load carrying. The operational bandwidth of the table is 0–20 Hz. Customized earthquake wave signals from real earthquakes can be simulated with the shaker. Figure 1.
MR damper experimental testbed.

The displacement of the base and first floors are measured by two LB-70 series laser displacement sensors by KEYENCE company. The measurement range is 100 mm ± 40 mm with fastest response time of 0.7 ms (with sensitivity of 180 µm) and a maximum sensitivity of 10 µm (at a response time of 500 ms). Accelerations of the second and the base floors are captured by microelectromechanical system (MEMS) accelerometers attached to each floor by wax. The type of accelerometer used is ADXL203EB Rev.0 by Analog Device company. The measurement range is ±1.7g, and the sensitivity is 1 mg in 60 Hz satisfying the requirements of the experiment, where g = 9.81 m/s2 is the standard gravity. The dSPACE board DS1103 RD, with controller and communication board CLP 1103, is used for the data acquisition purposes. This board is linked with Matlab/Simulink via analog-to-digital (A/D) and digital-to-analog (D/A) converters and controls input and output signals in real-time. Furthermore, an Agilent 6542A programmable power supply is connected to the dSPACE board output to amplify the voltage applied to the MR damper. The sampling rate is set to be 500 Hz.

The MR damper under study is a custom-made device built in the Smart Material and Structure Laboratory at the University of Houston. This device is a sponge-type damper that provides a stiction effect taken into account in parameter identification and controller design processes. The damper consists of a magnetic coil, MR fluid and a sliding bar. The coil is excited by the voltage applied to the MR damper which increases the viscosity of MR fluid and consequently the force exerted on the sliding bar. The amount of force produced is proportional to the area of active MR sponge exposed to the magnetic field. The MR damper is excited by voltages up to 8 V. The MR damper is attached between the base and a fixed point on the table to reduce the vibration of the structure. The damper stroke is ±2 cm and can produce a maximum force of about 10 N at the voltage of 8 V. The dynamic equation of motion for the structure including the MR damper (shown in Figure 2) is expressed as (1)Mq··+Cq·+Kq=ΓFmr-MΛx··g where q = [xb x1 x2]T, and Λ = [1 1 1]T and Γ = [−1 0 0]T are the distribution vectors. Here, xb, x1 and x2 denote the displacement of the base, first floor and second floor, respectively. The excitation x··g represents the ground acceleration. Figure 2.
Schematic of the experimental setup.

The mass, stiffness and damping matrices corresponding to the numerical model of the structure are M= [1.9580001.2580001.212 ] [kg],K= [2275.6-1218.60-1218.62716.3-1497.70-1497.71497.7 ] [N/m], C= [1.281-0.4870-0.4871.325-0.5990-0.5990.829 ] [N.s/m] where the natural frequencies of the system are 2.1, 5.48 and 9 Hz. The damping matrix above was considered to be proportional, i.e. C = a0M + a1K. Along with M and K, the coefficients a0 and a1 were also determined, where a0 = 0.1893 and a1 = 0.0004. It is noted that a damping ratio of 1% has been considered for all the structural modes. The stiffness and damping coefficients corresponding to the base floor include the stiffness of the springs attached to the base and damping effect of the slider, respectively.

sec.title: 3. LPV modeling and control design
sec.p:
Modified Bingham and LuGre-based models have been proposed to capture the dynamic behavior of a MR damper with stiction effect (Shirazi et al., 2011). The parameters of the Bingham and LuGre models can be identified by solving a nonlinear optimization problem, and the identified models are validated experimentally for different operating conditions. In the present work, the MR damper is used to attenuate the vibration of a two-story model structure by designing a LPV controller where the base velocity is used as the scheduling parameter. The Bingham model, which has a simpler structure than other existing models, is employed to capture the nonlinear dynamics of the damper. Considering the stiction effect, the force produced by the MR damper is given by (2)Fmr=(fa+fbV)sign(x·)+(c0x·+c0vx·V)e-(x·v0)2 where Fmr is the MR damper force when in motion (N), V is the input voltage (V), fa is the Coulomb frictional force (N), fb is the Coulomb frictional force influenced by voltage V (N/V), c0 is the viscous damping coefficient (N.s/m), c0v is the viscous damping coefficient influenced by voltage V (N.s/(m.V)), and v0 is the normalizing velocity (m/s). This model is valid for non-zero velocities. The exponential term introduced in the model capture two effects: (i) the flattening effect expected at high velocities; and (ii) the stiction effect in low forces. The first effect is physically motivated by the change of the damping characteristics as the velocity increases due to more lubricant being forced into the interface. The second effect is more significant in low forces in which bumpy responses are observed in velocities close to zero. The numerical values used for the Bingham model are summarized in Table 1. By assuming ξ=[q q·]T, (1) can be rewritten in the state-space form as (3)ξ·= [0I-M-1K-M-1C ]ξ+ [0-Λ ]x··g+ [0M-1Γ ]Fmr where Fmr is the control input acting on the structure. It is noted, however, that the MR damper force cannot be directly controlled; instead the voltage is the control input. Table 1.
Numerical values corresponding to the Bingham model
fa (N) fb (N/V) c0 (N.s/m) c0 v (N.s/m.V) v0 (m/s)
0.35 0.05 26.7 3.1 0.5

It is desirable to represent the nonlinear model obtained from combining (1) and (2) into an equivalent LPV form. To this purpose, we determine a quasi-LPV (qLPV) representation of the system model. qLPV systems represent a special class of LPV systems where the scheduling variables contain system states (Shamma and Cloutier, 1993). To proceed with the qLPV modeling of the system under study, we replace the MR damper force with the modified Bingham model in (2). Therefore, the equation of motion for the base mass is rewritten as mbx··b+c1(x·b-x·1)+cbx·b+c0x·be-(x·bv0)2+k1(xb-x1)+kbxb =-fasign(x·b)+(-fbsign(x·b)-c0vx·be-(x·bv0)2)V-mbx··g. Thus, we can rewrite (1) as follows considering the voltage as the input instead of the damper force (4)Mq··+Cmq·+Kq=ΓmV-MΛx··g where the modified matrices Cm and Γm are defined as Cm= [c11+fasign(x·b)x·b+c0e- (x·bv0 )2c120c12c22c230c23c33 ]Γm= [-fbsign(x·b)-c0vx·be- (x·bv0 )200 ] where the cij are the elements of the system damping matrix C. By substituting the above matrices in (3) and considering the base velocity x·b as the LPV parameter ρ, the following qLPV representation of the system is obtained ξ·= [0I-M-1K-M-1Cm(ρ) ]ξ+ [0-Λ ]d + [0M-1Γm(ρ) ]V=Aξ+B1d+B2V, where d=x··g is the ground acceleration considered to be the external disturbance input. It is noted that the base velocity is obtained by low-pass filtering and differentiating the base displacement. In this qLPV model, the system matrices A and B2 are dependent on the scheduling parameter. Hence, an ℋ∞ LPV controller can be designed to reduce the second floor absolute acceleration due to the earthquake excitation by solving a LMI optimization problem (Gahinet and Apkarian, 1994). For this purpose, dynamic weights are selected to shape the closed-loop transfer functions. Since we have a regulation problem and tracking is not of concern, we only need to shape the closed-loop transfer functions S and KS in a mixed sensitivity ℋ∞ control design formulation (Skogestad and Postlethwaite, 2005). We recall that S is the transfer function between the disturbance d and the output y, and KS is the transfer function between d and the control signal u. The controlled output vector is assumed to be e = [e1, e2]T = [Wsy, −Wuu]T as shown in Figure 3. In Figure 3, G represents the open-loop system described by (4). The absolute acceleration of the second floor is considered as the measured output y=x··2+x··g. The dynamic weights for the ℋ∞ control design are chosen to be Wu=2×10-4ss+20, Ws=1.4s2+0.9s+8 where Wu is the weight on the control input selected to be a high pass filter to penalize the control input over frequencies higher than 3.18 Hz. On the other hand, Ws is the weight on the output. This weight begins rolling off before the first natural frequency of the system which is 2.1 Hz. In general, there are two parameter-dependent matrices X and Y in the LMI synthesis conditions corresponding to the LPV ℋ∞ control design (Apkarian and Adams, 1998). One of the Lyapunov matrices Y is set to be linearly dependent on the scheduling parameter, that is, Y = Y0 + ρY1 and the other one is considered to be fixed, i.e. X = X0. The scheduling parameter is chosen to be the damper velocity ρ=x·b for which variation and rate bounds are given as follows ρ ∈ [−0.3, 0.3] m/s and ρ·∈[-5,5] m/s2. The corresponding synthesis LMIs are solved by gridding the parameter space for ρ over its range of variation following the procedure described by Apkarian and Adams (1998). Figure 3.
Mixed-sensitivity ℋ∞ control design configuration (Skogestad and Postlethwaite, 2005).

sec.title: 4. LPV anti-windup control
sec.p:
There are two methods for LPV anti-windup control design in the presence of actuator saturation. One approach involves the design of the feedback controller in a way to account for actuator nonlinearities. Wu et al. (2000) employed this method to design a LPV anti-windup controller by using a saturation indicator parameter and applied the method to control a linearized aircraft model. This method is beneficial only if a parameter-varying dynamic weight on the control input u is used. The aforementioned method was employed by Meisami-Azad et al. (2009) for control of a mechanical system including a MR damper. A second approach to design anti-windup controllers is based on the traditional two-step approach, where one first designs a controller disregarding the actuator saturation and then adds the anti-windup compensator to accommodate the saturations (Wu et al., 2003). In this formulation, the anti-windup controller does not affect the system if saturation is not present. The structure of this method is depicted in Figure 4, in which the arrow indicates the adaptation of the corresponding block with the scheduling parameter. In the present paper, we focus on the second anti-windup design method described above due to its ability to provide a two degree-of-freedom design configuration. Figure 4.
LPV anti-windup control scheme.

To formulate the problem, we consider a LPV system model augmented with the design weights represented by P (as shown in Figure 4) that has the state-space representation (5) [x·pey ]= [Ap(ρ)Bp1(ρ)Bp2(ρ)Cp1(ρ)Dp11(ρ)Dp12(ρ)Cp2(ρ)Dp21(ρ)Dp22(ρ) ] [xpdσ(u) ] where xp ∈ Rnp, y ∈ Rny, σ(u) ∈ Rnu, e ∈ Rne, and d ∈ Rnd are the augmented system state, the measurement vector, the saturated control input, the controlled output and the disturbance input, respectively.

The actuator nonlinearities we consider are in the form (6)σ(ui)= {ui |ui|<ui maxsign(ui)ui max |ui|≥ui max where ui max is the constant saturation limit for the ith actuator. To capture the actuator constraints in (6), we define the following parameter (7)qi(ui)=ui-σ(ui) which results in the behavior shown in Figure 5, where the slope of the line hi ∈ (0, 1). Assuming in general nu control inputs, we define a saturation matrix as ℋ = diag(h1, h2,…, hnu). Figure 5.
Saturation nonlinearity representation.

We assume that in (5), (Ap(ρ), Bp2(ρ)) and (Ap(ρ), Cp2(ρ)) are parameter-dependent stabilizable and detectable for all ρ, respectively, and that the matrices [B p2 T(ρ) D p12 T(ρ)] and [Cp2(ρ) Dp21(ρ)] have full row rank, and Dp22 = 0. A nominal LPV controller is designed first by ignoring the actuator saturation using the systematic control design approach in LPV control theory (Apkarian and Adams, 1998). If such a controller exists we pursue with designing a LPV anti-windup compensator such that the adverse effect of input saturations are mitigated in terms of the induced L2 norm. The dynamic of the anti-windup compensator (depicted by AW in Figure 4) is represented by (8) [x·awυ ]= [Aaw(ρ,ρ·)Baw(ρ,ρ·)Caw(ρ,ρ·)Daw(ρ,ρ·) ] [xawq ]. The controller K will then be in the form (9) [x·ku ]= [Ak(ρ,ρ·)Bk(ρ,ρ·)Ck(ρ,ρ·)Dk(ρ,ρ·) ] [xky ]+ [υ1υ2 ] where υ= [υ1 Tυ2 T ]T with υ1 ∈ Rnp and υ2 ∈ Rnu. The system matrices Ak, Bk, Ck, Dk are the state-space representation of the designed unconstrained controller, whereas Aaw, Baw, Caw, Daw are the state-space matrices of the anti-windup compensator. The LPV anti-windup control design problem can be then recast into a robust LPV control problem setting where the uncertainties are in the form q=Δu where Δi=1-σ(ui)ui and Δ = diag(Δ1,…, Δnu). For the sake of completeness, we review the following two theorems which are used to design the LPV anti-windup compensator considering that the nominal LPV controller K exists (Wu et al., 2003).

statement.title: Theorem 1
statement.p:
Given a constant matrix ℋ and a positive constant γ, the open-loop LPV system P described by (5) and a parameter-dependent stabilizing nominal controller K described by the state-space matrices Ak, Bk, Ck, and Dk in (9), if there exists a pair of positive-definite matrix functions R11(ρ), S(ρ) and a diagonal matrix function V(ρ) satisfying (10) [R11(ρ)A p T(ρ)+(⋆)-∑i=1 sρ·i∂R11(ρ)∂ρi +2Bp2(ρ)H-1V(ρ)(I-H-1)B p2 T(ρ)Cp1(ρ)R11(ρ)+2Dp12(ρ)H-1V(ρ)(I-H-1)B p2 T(ρ)Bp1 T(ρ)
(11) **-γIne+2Dp12(ρ)H-1V(ρ)(I-H-1)D p12 T(ρ)*Dp11 T(ρ)-γInd ]<0 [S(ρ)Aa(ρ,ρ·)+(⋆)+∑i=1 sρ·i∂S(ρ)∂ρiS(ρ)Ba1(ρ)Ca1 T(ρ)*-γIndDa11 T(ρ)**-γIne ]<0
(12) [R11(ρ) [Inp0 ] [Inp0 ]S(ρ) ]>0 for all (ρ,ρ·), then there exists an npth-order LPV anti-windup compensator to stabilize the closed-loop system exponentially and guarantee that ‖e‖2 < γ‖d‖2, where ‖.‖ is the vector's 2-norm. In the inequalities, and linear equations in Theorems 1 and 2, Aa= [Ap(ρ)+Bp2(ρ)Dk(ρ)Cp2(ρ)Bp2(ρ)Ck(ρ)Bk(ρ)Cp2(ρ)Ak(ρ,ρ·) ],Bao(ρ)= [-Bp2(ρ)0 ],Ba1(ρ)= [Bp1(ρ)+Bp2(ρ)Dk(ρ)Dp21(ρ)Bk(ρ)Dp21(ρ) ],Ba2(ρ)= [0Bp2(ρ)I0 ],Ca0= [Dk(ρ)Cp2(ρ)Ck(ρ) ],Ca1= [Cp1(ρ)+Dp12(ρ)Dk(ρ)Cp2(ρ)Dp12(ρ)Ck(ρ) ],Da01=Dk(ρ)Dp21(ρ), Da10=-Dp12,Da11=Dp11(ρ)Dk(ρ)Dp21(ρ), and s is the number of LPV parameters.

sec.p: After determining the parameter-dependent matrix variables from the solution to the set of inequalities above, the anti-windup compensator can be constructed.

statement.title: Theorem 2
statement.p:
If there is a feasible solution to the set of LMIs (10)–(12) in terms of the parameter-dependent matrices R11(ρ), S(ρ), and V(ρ) the LPV anti-windup compensator (8) can be determined from the following procedure:
First, construct the following matrices R(ρ)= [R11(ρ) [Inp0 ]S-1(ρ) [0Inp ] [0Inp ]S-1(ρ) [Inp0 ] [0Inp ]S-1(ρ) [0Inp ] ],
W(ρ)=V-1(ρ), M(ρ)N T(ρ)=In-R(ρ)S(ρ), E T= [Inp0 ], and find a feasible D∧aw(ρ) such that the following LMI holds true: (13)Π(ρ)= [-W(ρ)HD∧aw(ρ)+(⋆)+2W(ρ)**-Da01 THW(ρ)γInd*-Da10(ρ)-Dp12(ρ)D∧aw(ρ)-Da11(ρ)γIne ]>0 for all ρ.
Solve the following linear equations to obtain B∧aw(ρ)∈Rn×nu and C∧aw(ρ)∈Rnu×np (14) [0***Inu0-Π(ρ)0 ] [B∧aw T(ρ)? ]=- [0nu×nBa0 T(ρ)S(ρ)+W(ρ)HCa0(ρ)Ba1 T(ρ)S(ρ)Ca1(ρ) ], [0***W(ρ)H0-Π(ρ)Dp12 ] [C∧aw(ρ)? ]=- [B p2 T(ρ)(Ba0 T(ρ)+W(ρ)HCa0(ρ)R(ρ))E+D∧aw T(ρ)Bp2 T(ρ)Ba1 T(ρ)ECa1(ρ)R(ρ)E ]. Then A∧aw(ρ,ρ·)∈Rn×np is determined from (15)A∧aw(ρ,ρ·)=-ρ·dS(ρ)dρR(ρ)E-ρ·dN(ρ)dρM T(ρ)E-Aa T(ρ,ρ·)E- [S(ρ)Ba0(ρ)+B∧aw(ρ)+Ca0 T(ρ)HW(ρ)S(ρ)Ba1(ρ) Ca1 T(ρ) ]Π-1(ρ) × [(Ba0 T(ρ)+W(ρ)HCa0(ρ)R(ρ))E+D∧aw T(ρ)Bp2 T(ρ) +W(ρ)HC∧aw(ρ)Ba1 T(ρ)ECa1(ρ)R(ρ)E+Dp12(ρ)C∧aw(ρ) ].
Finally, the anti-windup compensator matrices are obtained from (16) [Aaw(ρ,ρ·)Baw(ρ)Caw(ρ,ρ·)Daw(ρ) ]= [N(ρ)S(ρ)Ba2(ρ)0 [0Inu ] ]-1 × ( [A∧aw(ρ,ρ·)B∧aw(ρ)C∧aw(ρ)D∧aw(ρ) ] - [S(ρ)Aa(ρ,ρ·)R(ρ)E000nu×nu ] ) × [M T(ρ)E00Inu ]-1.

sec.p: In the above formulations (⋆) denotes the transpose of the terms it proceeds and * is used to denote the sub-matrices lying under the main diagonal. Proofs of these results can be found in the literature (Wu et al., 2003).

sec.title: 5. Experimental results
sec.p:
For control design validation, two types of well-known earthquake signal forms namely the Northridge and the El Centro are applied as disturbance input to the shaker table described in Section 2. The intensities of the Northridge and El Centro signals are 0.7g and 0.6g, respectively. Figure 6 shows the two earthquake signals which basically represent the ground acceleration. The following control design methods are implemented and compared in the MR damper experimental testbed using the above excitation signals:
a LPV anti-windup controller designed using the approach described in sections 3 and 4 with the closed-loop configuration shown in Figure 4;
a LPV controller ignoring the actuator saturation with a design configuration similar to Figure 4 with no anti-windup compensator in place; and
a conventional anti-windup scheme which is an auxiliary loop compensator seeking to accommodate the discrepancy between the controller output and plant input.
Figure 6.
El Centro and Northridge earthquake excitations.

The LPV anti-windup controller is designed by solving the corresponding LMIs via gridding over the range of base velocity. Gridding is a standard approach to convert infinite-dimensional LMI constraints in the LPV synthesis problem to a set of finite-dimensional LMIs (Apkarian and Adams, 1998). For simplicity, we consider constant basis functions for the Lyapunov functions R11, S, and V in the corresponding synthesis LMIs. The corresponding level of ℒ2-gain is determined to be γ = 6.08.

First, we compare cases (i) and (ii), i.e. the designed LPV anti-windup compensator as in Figure 4 with the case with no anti-windup compensation but with a saturation limit of zero and eight volts, for El Centro 0.6g excitation. The second floor acceleration is shown in Figure 7. The maximum peak of the second floor acceleration for the cases (i) and (ii) is determined to be 4.89 and 4.91, respectively. The RMS for the second floor acceleration for the cases (i) and (ii) is calculated to be 72.72 and 73.38, respectively. The control input signal which is the MR damper voltage is depicted in Figure 8. The voltage shown is basically the controller output before it is saturated and applied to the semi-active damper. It is observed that the MR damper voltage using the anti-windup compensator is within the allowable range and the performance of the controller is slightly improved. The LPV parameter, based on which the controllers are scheduled is shown in Figure 9. Figure 7.
Second floor acceleration corresponding to El Centro 0.6g.
Figure 8.
Control input (MR damper voltage) corresponding to El Centro 0.6g.
Figure 9.
Profile of the scheduling parameter (base velocity in m/s) corresponding to El Centro 0.6g.

Similar results are obtained by comparing the two cases discussed earlier when the structure is excited using the Northridge 0.7g earthquake. The results are illustrated in Figures 10, 11 and 12. Based on the results, the maximum peaks of the second floor acceleration for the cases (i) and (ii) are found out to be 5.62 and 5.67, respectively. The RMS values for the second floor acceleration for the two cases (i) and (ii) are 70.24 and 68.37, respectively. The results illustrate that the LPV anti-windup compensation along with the LPV controller has been able to keep the MR damper voltage within the allowable range; however, its closed-loop performance (in terms of the acceleration peak) has been slightly degraded compared with that of the LPV controller with no anti-windup compensation. This is well justified, since desirable design requirements for the anti-windup compensation subject to actuator saturation are the closed-loop system stability, recovery of the linear design specifications in the absence of saturation (linear performance recovery), and the smooth degradation of the linear performance in the presence of saturation (graceful performance degradation) (Wu et al., 2003). As observed, the use of an anti-windup controller in the inner loop in Figure 4 results in lower control input, i.e. MR damper voltage, and thus a reduction in the power consumption. Figure 10.
Second floor acceleration corresponding to Northridge 0.7g.
Figure 11.
Control input (MR damper voltage) corresponding to Northridge 0.7g.
Figure 12.
Profile of the scheduling parameter in m/s corresponding to Northridge 0.7g.

Next, we compare the results of the designed LPV anti-windup controller (case (i)) with those of a conventional anti-windup scheme (case (iii)). A generic anti-windup scheme is shown in Figure 13, where G(s) and K(s) represent the plant and controller, respectively, while R(s) represents a compensator which feeds back the error between the output from the controller and input to the plant. In the classical anti-windup design this compensator is chosen to be R(s) = α/s, where the scalar α represents a tunable design parameter (Edwards and Postlethwaite, 1998). It is noted that this anti-windup compensation scheme is different from that depicted in Figure 4. This is because in Figure 4 the anti-windup compensator's output is an input to the LPV controller K(s) whereas in Figure 13 an auxiliary loop is added to drive the saturation error to zero by using an integrator. The comparison plots are shown in Figures 14 and 15 for the El Centro earthquake test signal. Although the acceleration responses are very similar the voltage input using the LPV anti-windup is meeting the maximum allowable MR damper voltage. The voltage comparison between the classical anti-windup control and the proposed LPV anti-windup control for the Northridge earthquake is also shown in Figure 16. Figure 13.
Classical anti-windup scheme.
Figure 14.
Second floor acceleration corresponding to El Centro 0.6g for a classical anti-windup and a LPV anti-windup design.
Figure 15.
Control input (MR damper voltage) corresponding to El Centro 0.6g.
Figure 16.
Control input (MR damper voltage) corresponding to Northridge 0.7g.

We have summarized the results of the experiments in Tables 2 and 3 where the peak and RMS values of the second floor acceleration as well as the RMS value of the MR damper voltage for three different LPV control strategies discussed in this paper are reported. As the results reported in Tables 2 and 3 illustrate, the proposed anti-windup design method has led to a decrease in both voltage RMS and peak values compared with the LPV design allowing actuator saturation, as well as the standard anti-windup control design. It is noted that the lower-voltage RMS value represents a reduction in power consumption. In summary, the reduced power consumption due to the lower voltage levels while maintaining the closed-loop system performance justifies the use of a LPV anti-windup controller, where the controller state-space matrices are scheduled with respect to the MR damper velocity. Table 2.
Peak and root mean square (RMS) values of the experimental results for El Centro 0.6g test signal
Controller type Second floor acceleration RMS (cm/s2) Second floor acceleration peak (m/s2) MR damper voltage RMS (V) MR damper voltage peak (V)
LPV 73.38 4.91 1.426 15.885
Classical anti-windup 71.99 4.82 1.309 10.175
Proposed LPV anti-windup 72.72 4.89 1.235 8.317
Table 3.
Peak and root mean square (RMS) values of the experimental results for Northridge 0.7g test signal
Controller type Second floor acceleration RMS (cm/s2) Second floor acceleration peak (m/s2) MR damper voltage RMS (V) MR damper voltage peak (V)
LPV 68.37 5.67 1.491 15.179
Classical anti-windup 69.71 5.38 1.258 11.316
Proposed LPV anti-windup 70.24 5.62 1.148 8.403

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, we have designed a LPV anti-windup compensator to complement a nominal LPV controller in order to reduce the vibration of a two-story model structure including a MR damper. Different earthquake signals with different intensities might demand a MR damper voltage out of the tolerable range. By making use of a LPV anti-windup controller, where MR damper velocity is considered to be the scheduling parameter in the LPV anti-windup control design process, the MR damper actuating voltage is kept within its allowable limits. The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the employed LPV controller combined with the LPV anti-windup scheme compared with the LPV controller (with no anti-windup compensation), as well as a conventional anti-windup compensation scheme.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
